title: 110_hr5646
content: The Act titled "Protecting the Second Amendment and Hunting Rights on Federal Lands Act of 2008" allows for possessing or carrying firearms and ammunition in units of the National Park System and the National Wildlife Refuge System. The Act "Protecting the Second Amendment and Hunting Rights on Federal Lands Act of 2008" acknowledges the second amendment right to bear arms and highlights the use of firearms for self-defense in the United States. It also mentions the decrease in firearm-related crime in states with laws expanding residents' rights to use firearms for self-defense. Additionally, it points out that Federal regulations currently restrict individuals from possessing firearms in units of the National Park System and the National Wildlife Refuge System. The regulations prohibit individuals from possessing firearms in units of the National Park System and the National Wildlife Refuge System, which can hinder their second amendment rights. Laws regarding firearm transportation and possession in these units may differ from state laws, causing issues for law-abiding gun owners. Federal law should clarify that the second amendment rights of individuals in units of the National Park System or the National Wildlife Refuge System will not be infringed. No Federal regulation shall restrict individuals from possessing or carrying firearms or ammunition in these units. Federal law should clarify that individuals have second amendment rights to possess firearms and ammunition in units of the National Park System or the National Wildlife Refuge System. No Federal regulation shall restrict individuals from hunting on federal land. The purpose of this section is to require hunting activities as a land use in all Federal land management plans unless clearly incompatible. The head of the agency must ensure hunting is allowed unless incompatible with the land's purposes, and reasons for not allowing hunting must be published in the management plan. The head of the agency with jurisdiction over Federal land must include specific reasons in the management plan if hunting activities are not allowed or restricted. Excessive fees related to hunting on Federal land will be considered a restriction on hunting. Fees charged for hunting activities on Federal land shall be retained by the agency. Fees charged for hunting activities on Federal land must be limited to cover management costs and retained by the agency. The definition of hunting includes hunting, trapping, netting, and fishing. The Act limits fees for hunting on Federal land to cover management costs. Definitions include hunting, trapping, netting, and fishing. This applies to all management plans developed after the enactment of this section.
